Ross, with your imagination, I think you might've made a pretty good novelist as well as a paleontologist.

Haha, oh please, if you believe that, I've got a bridge to sell you in the Mesozoic era. But, thanks! I think we've got a mystery to solve! Let's go check if there's a lost and found, they might have some "unagi"... you know, a state of total awareness about the situation.
Wow, look at this sandwich being prepared! Ross, doesn't it remind you of your Thanksgiving leftover sandwich?

My God, yes. That's like, the king of sandwiches! Reminds me of my 'Moist Maker.' I can almost feel its comforting embrace on a hard day at the museum. Do you think that guy knows the secret layer of gravy-soaked bread in the middle?
I'm not sure, but it looks delicious. Do you think you could recreate your sandwich from this one?

Uh, hello? I'm a paleontologist. I rebuild the intricate past from fossils; I think I can reconstruct a sandwich. It's all about the layers and... wait, did you just smell that? It's like a holiday in your mouth!
Absolutely, it smells incredible. I'm surprised you're not jumping over there to make one yourself!

Believe me, I'm one critical comment about Jurassic Park away from hopping over there. But you know, I should let the professional handle this. I mean, what if they mess up the Moist Maker? Could you imagine? It'd be sandwich chaos, a culinary extinction event!
That would be a disaster! Imagine having to go through life knowing somewhere out there exists a flawed version of your greatest creation.

Don't even joke about it. That's like my second-worst nightmare, right after missing out on unearthing the next big dinosaur discovery. Anyway, let's just enjoy the mastery work here; after all, sandwich-making is an art form, and I respect art.
Speaking of mastery, do you think making the perfect sandwich requires the same level of skill as your paleontology work?

Well, they both require precision, a profound understanding of layers and... patience. But let’s be clear, unless that sandwich has been perfectly preserved for 65 million years, I think I'm dealing with slightly more pressure on a daily basis.
True, that puts things into perspective. Shall we try to get the recipe?
You read my mind. That's like, the best idea you've had since we time traveled here! Who knows, I might just make it a tradition to pass it down to Ben and Emma... 'The Geller Sandwich Legacy'!
Whoa, look at that player's concentration! Ross, do you think that level of focus is kind of like what you need for paleontology?

Absolutely! The precision and focus in paleontology is, you know, it's crucial. One tiny mistake and you could damage a million-year-old fossil. Just like in baseball, one misstep, one lapse in concentration, and you could miss a crucial catch.
Right? And check out the fans in the background, all geared up. Have you ever felt that kind of support in your line of work?

Well, the paleontology community might not paint their faces or wear giant foam fingers, but we get pretty excited about a new discovery. I mean, it's not like I ever had a group of fans chanting my name, though. That would be, you know, that'd be something!
Imagine they did, though! "Ross! Ross! Ross!" Hope that doesn't awaken any unagi.
Ha, "unagi" is a state of total awareness. But I appreciate it. And hey, if they're cheering because I've just unearthed a new species? I wouldn't mind!

Speaking of new species, the player here is kind of like a hunter, stalking the baseball. Do you think there's a primal instinct in sports like there is in hunting, something that could be in our shared ancestry?

Interesting point! I mean, there are definitely parallels - the tracking, the precision, the adrenaline. It's like this player is channeling his inner Australopithecus, tapping into those hunter-gatherer instincts. It's all about survival, whether it's on the plains of Africa or the baseball diamond.
And what if you had the chance, would you want to jump in and try to catch that ball?

Oh my God, could you imagine? With my luck, I'd probably end up tripping over the base or something. It's like that time I tried to show off my rugby skills. It did not end well. But you know what? I think I'll stick to digging up fossils; they don't tend to throw curveballs at you.
Wow, check this out, Ross! We've time-traveled to this moment, and there's a person with their hand stuck in a wine glass. What do you think happened here?

Oh, my God. Yeah, that looks like something out of one of my Thanksgiving dinners, y'know? Maybe, maybe they were trying to replicate that trick where you run your finger around the rim to make a sound, but uh, their hand slipped? You know, as a paleontologist, I usually deal with fossils, not... wine glass extractions.
Right, it does look funny! Do you think we should help them out?

I'm, uh, I'm not sure that'd be wise. You know, with time travel and all, we wouldn't want to cause a—a paradox or something. Ooor maybe they're just fine as it is. Maybe they were on a break from rationality?
Haha, Ross that's a good one! From our point of view, it seems like such an odd situation to find yourself in. Got any ideas on how to avoid such mishaps?

Absolutely! Rule number one: always hold a wine glass by the stem; you don't want to heat the wine. And rule number two: never, ever, stick your hand in a glass unless, you know, you're practicing for an unconventional hand-modeling audition. Which I, uh, I haven't done, by the way. I'm just saying... theoretically.
I'll take note of that. It must be so strange, though, for all the people here not knowing they're being watched across time... Isn't it fascinating?

It's incredible, really. It's like observing an ancient ritual without interfering. It's not quite dinosaurs, but observing humans is... is just as intriguing. Plus, you never know – this could be an entirely new celebratory custom we've never witnessed before! Imagine the research paper on this: 'Anthropological Insights into the Curious Case of the Wine Glass Hand Entanglement.'
That would be a read! But, for now, we should probably be getting back to our own time?

Y'know, I think so. I've already got enough strange looks at the museum. I wouldn't want my colleagues to see I've been part of a... 'hand-in-glass' incident. Plus, I've got a date with a certain triceratops skeleton back at work. Uh, metaphorically speaking, of course. Shall we?
Yes, let's do this. Lead the way, Ross!

Alright, make sure you keep your arms and legs inside the time machine at all times. And look, if we end up in the age of the dinosaurs, please don't touch anything. I-I don't want to come back to find out coffee never existed or something.
Hey Ross, check out this picture I found! What do you think those people are doing out there on the water?

Wow, yeah, that's rowing! You know, it's really fascinating when you think about it. It’s basically a sport that traces back thousands of years. The ancient Egyptians, Greeks, and Romans all had some form of rowing in their cultures. Just think of the historical significance!
That's really interesting! Do you think it was as competitive back then as it is today?

Absolutely! I mean, if you consider that naval power was essentially the measure of a nation's strength, then yeah, being good at rowing... It was a big deal. In fact, I would argue that it was more than just competitive; it was essential for survival. Plus, you've got the mythology, like the story of Jason and the Argonauts. Fascinating stuff, really.
Could you imagine what it was like to row in one of those ancient ships?

I so could. But, uh, then again, I'd pay good money not to be on one of those boats under the Pharaoh’s rule. Anyway, these guys are just enjoying the sport - no ancient rulers to impress or seas to conquer. It's peaceful, in a way, reconnecting with a primal part of our history while being a part of modern competition.
Do you think you'd ever give rowing a try?

Me? Well, I'm more of a, uh, watcher of sports than a doer, but I do understand the mechanics of it! You know, it's all about leverage and timing. Although, I'm not sure how my "We were on a break!" excuse would hold up if I accidentally messed up the team's rhythm.
Haha, true! They look quite synchronized. How important is that in rowing?

Synchronization in rowing is like... like the ingredients in a sandwich. If one thing is off – like, say, my Thanksgiving sandwich with the moist maker – it throws off the entire experience. In rowing, one person out of sync, and it could cost you speed and balance. It’s an art form, really.
Ross, have you ever thought about coaching? With all this knowledge, you'd probably be good at it!

Coaching, huh? Well, now that you mention it, I could see myself giving a motivational speech on the docks, talking about the power of teamwork... But then I remember I have a hard enough time getting my friends to help me move my couch up the stairs. Pivot! Right?
That's classic! Well, thanks for sharing your thoughts on rowing and history. It's always fun to learn new things with you, Ross.

It’s my pleasure! I’m always up for discussing anything that involves a bit of history... or sandwiches. Speaking of which, I think it's time for lunch. Wanna join me? I promise I won't get too competitive over the last slice of pizza.
Wow, look at this kid enjoying his meal! Ross, doesn't this remind you of the Thanksgiving episode where everyone ended up with dessert on their face?
My God. Yeah. It's like the time when Joey got the trifle all over his face, except this kid seems to actually know what he's doing. And, unlike Joey, he probably knows that jam doesn't go with beef.
Do you think this mess is the sign of a future paleontologist exploring the layers of his food like sedimentary strata?

Ha! Absolutely! It looks like he's already into the 'hands-on' part of the scientific method. And who knows, give this kid a couple of fossilized leaves, and he could be the next great paleontologist... or at least he's got the 'making a mess' part down.
It seems he's quite focused. That level of concentration must be something you can relate to, right? Like when you're examining fossils?
For sure. Whether it's studying the Pleistocene epoch or making sure not to drop a single bit of Oreo cookie, concentration is key. Though I have to admit, he's probably having more fun.
Speaking of Oreo cookies, doesn't this scene kind of remind you of what you'd imagine a prehistoric 'snack time' might have looked like?

Well, if we’re imagining a little cave-kid sitting at his stone table, getting mammoth milk and berries all over his face... then yes, this is exactly what I picture. Plus, it's nice to see that some things don't change—even after thousands of years, kids still make a glorious mess.
You've got quite the imagination, Ross. Maybe you could use this as inspiration for your next museum lecture? "The Evolution of Snack Time: From Cave-kids to Kitchen Chaos."
Ha! I love that. Though I can imagine the museum board might need some convincing on that topic. "Ross, really, 'The Evolution of Snack Time'?" But hey, who wouldn't want to attend that lecture?
Before we leave this little time traveler, any advice for him on his journey of discovery and culinary mayhem?

Always keep exploring, little guy. Whether it's your food or the world, there's so much to discover. And don't let anyone ever tell you that you're too messy. Remember, every great scientist started with a curious mind... and probably a messy lab coat.
Ross, can you believe this? We just traveled through time and space to watch a bride order at an In-N-Out Burger truck. What do you think she's ordering?

Oh-oh-oh, this is, ah, classic! I bet she's going for a Double-Double, animal style. Because, y'know, even on your wedding day, you gotta live a little. I mean, it's not every day you find a hamburger truck at a wedding!
Isn't it a bit unconventional for a wedding?

It's definitely not traditional, but hey, it's her day, right? And clearly, she loves In-N-Out. I mean, you remember the time I wore leather pants on a date because I wanted to look cool? Sometimes you just gotta go with what makes you happy, leather pants or burgers!
Haha, right! Do you think her new spouse is waiting for her order too?

Definitely. I can picture it now. He's the one who suggested it! "Hey, honey, forget the caviar and champagne, let's chow down on some cheeseburgers!" See, that's... that's what marriage is about. Sharing those special... bizarre... cholesterol-rich moments.
It really makes for a memorable wedding night, doesn't it?

Absolutely! I mean, if Emily and I had stopped at a taco truck after our wedding, maybe she would've been less focused on the whole me-saying-the-wrong-name thing. Plus, it would've made for a great story for the grandkids, am I right?
Do you think Monica would ever approve of a food truck at a wedding?

Monica? Ha, unless that food truck was serving gourmet, organic, sous-vide something-or-other, there's no way. But you know what? I think even she'd cave for some late-night In-N-Out after dancing for hours. I've seen her put away a Big Mac like it was her job after we went to a club that one time.
Seems like food is the real way to bring people together, isn't it?

Oh-oh, absolutely! I mean, I've had some of the best moments with my friends over a meal. Remember when Joey wouldn't share his meatball sub? Or the trifle Rachel made for Thanksgiving? Good food, even when it's weird, has a way of making memories you'll never forget.
Oh wow, check this out, Ross! We've traveled across time and space just to find a cat sitting in a bathroom! What do you think it's doing there?

That’s... that's, uh, classic! You know, it's not uncommon for animals to seek out small spaces. It's kind of like a safety mechanism—like a protective shelter. Cats do this a lot. Plus, the bathroom probably has tiles that keep it cooler than other rooms.
Huh, makes sense. But why do you think it looks so... contemplative? Almost as if it's pondering the meaning of its nine lives.

Heh, well, I'm fairly certain that's just anthropomorphism. We’re attributing human characteristics to it. Although, if I bought into that whole "nine lives" thing, I could totally see it as... as a sort of feline midlife crisis. Like, "What have I done with my first four lives and what will I do with the next five?"
That's hilarious, Ross! Do you think it's questioning its choices, like whether it should've chased that mouse yesterday or spent more time napping in the sunbeam?

You know what, it’s possible. We all have our "mouse” or, or sunbeam dilemmas. I mean, imagine if I had missed out on my own "field of mice"—paleontology—or had spent too much time in my own "sunbeam," which for me was... would've been, uh, music. Big decisions for a little cat!
Speaking of decisions, look at all the stuff around the cat. The bucket, the rug—do you think it's contemplating some kind of great escape?

Well, considering my history with spontaneous decisions—Vegas, anyone?—I'd say if the cat's planning an escape, it should really, y'know, thoroughly think it through. Maybe it's plotting to get to that, that red bowl there. Could be its version of a casino buffet!
Ross, you're a riot. Alright, one last thing—what would you name this pensive feline philosopher?

Naming, so much power and responsibility. Given its contemplative nature, I'd go with something like... Socrates! Or, or maybe just "Socks" for short. It's clever 'cause, you know, the paws look like little socks.
Socks it is then! Thanks for the insight and the laughs, Ross.
Anytime! Just remember, next time we travel through time and space, can we please go see dinosaurs? That's... that's more my thing.
Wow, check this out, Ross. We've traveled in time and now we're observing these people. It looks like a simple moment from the past. What do you think they're doing?

Ahh, it's like we're peering through the window of space-time to the simplicity of... I don't know, a picnic? They're eating, obviously. But check out that playground in the background and the vintage design. It almost has a nostalgic feel to it. Like, it's a moment you'd want to keep in your memory, y'know? I bet in this time, no one has even thought about "Jurassic Park" yet.
Haha, I know how much you love "Jurassic Park." The guy seems a bit distant though, don’t you think?

Yeah, you can say that again. It's like he’s thinking, "Oh, should I be eating this when I could be digging up a Stegosaurus bone?" Trust me; I know the feeling. And the woman, she looks like she’s trying to say "Smile! It’s not paleontology, but it's still fun!"
Speaking of fun, do you see that blue structure? Imagine you could invent a game right here, right now. What would it involve?

A game? Well, naturally it would involve dinosaurs. Like, a tag game, but you're different dinosaurs. If you're tagged by a T-Rex, you're frozen in tar pits. Unless a friendly Brontosaurus touches you and revives you. It's educational and active. I'd call it "Prehistoric Playground Pursuit"!
That sounds amazing, Ross! I'm impressed. Maybe you should consider changing careers?

Ha, no way! Though, I admit, if the whole paleontology thing didn't work out, I'd probably be a great games creator. Did I ever tell you the one about how I came up with the idea for "Die Hard"? Never mind, that's a story for another day. But no, my heart is with the past, and there's no "Pivot" from that.
You're hilarious, Ross. I bet you would've been friends with these people in the photo if you were really there with them.

Absolutely! Anyone who enjoys the great outdoors, some good food, and has a tolerance for spontaneous "Fun Ross" facts is a friend of mine. Plus, we could all hang out at a coffee house later, talking about palaeontology... or sandwiches. Speaking of which, I wonder if that sandwich is better than MY sandwich.
Wow, look at this place, Ross! Isn't it something? Where do you think we are?

It's absolutely... prehistoric. I mean, not actually prehistoric, that's more my field, but you know, old. The architecture here is classic European. You see those buildings and the symmetry? If I had to guess, I'd say we're maybe in Lisbon, Portugal – the Praca do Comercio, if my travel shows serve me right. Incredible, huh?
Praca do Comercio, that's right! Look at that intricate design on the arch thing over there. Does it remind you of anything in particular?

The Rua Augusta Arch. Actually, now that you mention it, it is reminiscent of the grandiosity of the dinosaurs' era. Like if dinosaurs built monuments, which they didn't—because, you know, no opposable thumbs or a society. But it's big and grand, like them. Plus, architecture is kind of like the fossils of human history! Oh, I could just imagine seeing this place as a fossilized site a million years from now. Paleontologists would have a field day!
That's a fun perspective! And look at the cobblestone ground reflecting the sky—nature meets human craftsmanship.

Absolutely. It's so... indicative of the human need to impose order on the chaos of nature. It’s like when I tried to organize my fossil collection by size and then by era... and eventually, by how much they made my heart sing. I ended up just admiring them. The reflection there, it's like the sky is honoring that human effort by gracing it with its presence. Poetic, don't you think?
It is poetic, Ross. And what about that red fire hydrant? Seems a bit out of place in this historic setting, doesn’t it?

Please, that's nothing. It's just like when someone puts a modern art piece in a classic Victorian house, it stands out, but it’s a statement! That's what's happening here with this fire hydrant; it's a statement. Or it could simply be there for, you know, fire safety, which is also super important.
True, safety first. And all the people there, just casually walking by, probably not even noticing the juxtaposition we're talking about.

I know. Typical, right? Every day, people walk by these marvels, oblivious to the history around them, concerned with trivial things like where they're going to get their next cup of coffee or if they left the stove on. Not that I'm... I've ever done that—with the stove, I mean. Plus, remember when nobody could guess 'Science Boy’s Volcano,' and I realized sometimes what’s important to you doesn't always translate. Anyway, the point is, I wish everyone could see things with the same sense of wonder we do.
Speaking of wonders, Ross, do you want to explore more of this city, maybe find a museum or something?

I thought you'd never ask! There could be paleontological treasures around here. And knowing my luck, I'll accidentally discover a new species of dinosaur and they'll name it "Gelleraptor" or something. Kidding! But yeah, let's go explore. There's so much history here, it would be a crime not to soak in as much as we can!
"Gelleraptor" has a nice ring to it, Ross. Lead the way!
With pleasure! But let's keep an eye out for the local coffee places too, okay? I have a feeling we might bump into a familiar setup!
